The Jewish Museum. | birth_name = | birth_date = 1871 | birth_place = | death_date = 1952 | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | nationality = American | other_names = | known_for = Art collector | education = | employer = | occupation = Banker | title = | salary = | networth = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | spouse = | children = | parents = | relatives = | box_width = }} [[File:Jean-Baptiste Siméon Chardin 022.jpg|thumbnail|[[Jean Siméon Chardin]], ''Soap Bubbles''. Oil on canvas. Ex David David-Weill Collection. Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York.<ref>[http://www.metmuseum.org/collection/the-collection-online/search/435888?=&imgno=0&tabname=object-information ''Soap Bubbles''.] [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]. Retrieved 16 February 2015.</ref>]] [[File:Dans-la-prairie-by-Claude-001.jpg|thumbnail|[[Claude Monet]], ''Dans la Prairie''. Ex David David-Weill Collection.<ref>[http://www.christies.com/lotfinder/paintings/claude-monet-dans-la-prairie-5176268-details.aspx Sale 7701, Lot. 19.] Christie's. Retrieved 16 February 2015.</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2009/feb/05/monet-oil-auction-christies "Monet oil tests art market."] Mark Brown, ''[[The Guardian]]'', 5 February 2009. Retrieved 16 February 2015.</ref>]] '''David David-Weill''' (1871-1952) was a French-American banker, chairman of Lazard Frères in Paris, who built an important collection of art. His collection was plundered by the [[Nazi Germany|Nazis]] during the Second World War and over 2000 items seized. He was a major donor to French and American museums and galleries and a benefactor to universities.
==Early life and family== David-Weill was born in San Francisco on 30 August 1871.<ref name=dumb>[http://www.doaks.org/resources/bliss-tyler-correspondence/annotations/david-david-weill David David-Weill.] Dumbarton Oaks. Retrieved 10 February 2015.</ref> He was the son of Julie (née Cahn) and [[:fr:Alexandre Weill (banquier)]] (1834-1906). His father was a cousin to the three French Jewish brothers who founded [[Lazard Frères & Co.]]. His parents had left France in 1870 because of the [[Franco-Prussian War]] and settled in California, where [[Raphael Weill]], a brother of Alexandre Weill lived. They returned to France about 1883. David-Weill continued his education there at the [[Lycée Condorcet]] and the [[École Libre des Sciences Politiques]]. He married Flora Raphael in 1897 and they had seven children, including [[Pierre David-Weill]] and [[Jean David-Weill]].
==Banking career== Following his education, David-Weill performed his military service and began to work at Lazard Frères, where he rose to become chairman. He became regent of the [[Banque de France]] in 1935.
==Collecting== David-Weill began to collect from an early age. His acquisitions included paintings, drawings, miniatures, sculpture, furniture, silverware and other items. He became president of the council of French national museums and vice president of the Friends of the Louvre.<ref name=dumb/>
His collection was looted by the Nazis during the Second World War and, according to German records, 2687 items seized.<ref name=Harc>Harclerode, Peter, & Brendan Pittaway. (1999) ''The Lost Masters: The Looting of Europe's Treasurehouses''. London: [[Victor Gollancz]], p. 44. {{ISBN|0575052546}}</ref>
In later life he donated more than 2000 items to museums and galleries, including the [[Guimet Museum]], the [[Louvre]], and universities at New York, Hamburg, Leiden, Honolulu, and Stockholm. He donated to the libraries of the Museum of Man and the National Institute of Art History, to which he gave the manuscript and journal of [[Eugène Delacroix]]. He gave his Chinese bronzes to the [[Musée Guimet]], and his [[cloisonné]] objects to the Musée des Arts Décoratifs.<ref name=dumb/>
==Death== David-Weill died in [[Neuilly-sur-Seine]] on 7 July 1952.<ref name=dumb/> Parts of his collection were sold in a series of auctions in 1970.
==Honours== [[File:P1110765 Paris XIV avenue David-Weill rwk.JPG|thumbnail|Avenue David-Weill, Paris.]] *David-Weill was elected to the [[Académie des beaux-arts]] in 1934. *Avenue David-Weill in the [[14th arrondissement of Paris]] was named in his honour in 1960 in tribute to his involvement with the [[Cité internationale universitaire de Paris]].
==See also== *[[Michel David-Weill]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==Further reading== *Henriot, Gabriel. (1926) ''Collection David-Weill''. Paris: Presses de Braun. (3 vols.)

[[Henry Ian Cusick]] | released = {{Film date|2009|2|17}} | runtime = 87 minutes | country = United States | language = English | distributor = [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] }} '''''Dead like Me: Life After Death''''' is a 2009 [[Direct-to-video#The direct-to-DVD market|direct-to-video]] film directed by [[Stephen Herek]].{{cite news|url = http://www.scifi.com/scifiwire/index.php?category=3&id=41125|title = MGM Announces SF DVD Slate|work = Sci Fi Wire|publisher = SciFi.com|date = April 18, 2007|accessdate = April 18, 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070420043114/http://www.scifi.com/scifiwire/index.php?category=3&id=41125 |archivedate = April 20, 2007}} The film is based on the short-lived 2003 television series ''[[Dead Like Me]]'' created by [[Bryan Fuller]]. In the film, the "reapers" have a new boss, Kane, who leads them astray from the rules they followed (mostly) in the TV series. Lead character "George" is fired from her job at "Happy Time" and ends up revealing her identity to her sister, Reggie. George's fellow reapers confront Kane and find that he knows and doesn't care that their departure from the job rules is causing misfortune elsewhere. Unhappy with his leadership, they try various ways to end his existence. George gets her Happy Time job back, and then learns who the new boss of the reapers is. [[Laura Harris]] was unavailable to return for her role as Daisy Adair, and [[Sarah Wynter]] played the part. The rest of the returning cast was portrayed by the same actors as in the TV series, with new character Cameron Kane played by [[Henry Ian Cusick]]. The film was released on February 17, 2009 after a month-prior debut on Canada's [[Super Channel (Canada)|SuperChannel]]. == Plot == A crew of "reapers", whose job is to extract the souls of people who are about to die, find themselves confronted by change as their habitual meeting place (Der Waffle Haus) burns down on the same day that their boss and head reaper ([[Rube John Sofer|Rube]]) disappears (having "gotten his lights"). They soon meet their new boss, Cameron Kane ([[Henry Ian Cusick]]), a slick businessman who died falling from the [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]] on [[September 11 attacks|September 11, 2001]]. He outfits them with color-coordinated [[Palm Treo|smartphone]]s and treats them to luxurious accommodations – teaching them, as [[List of Dead Like Me characters#Roxy Harvey|Roxy]] ([[Jasmine Guy]]) puts it later, that "nothing we do here matters." This tutelage leads the reapers to perform such misdeeds as saving those they were to Reap (Roxy), abusing immortality for financial gain ([[List of Dead Like Me characters#Mason|Mason]], played by [[Callum Blue]]), letting a soul wander, instead of showing him "his lights" ([[List of Dead Like Me characters#Daisy Adair|Daisy]], now played by [[Sarah Wynter]]), and otherwise selfishly focusing on their wants.{{cite video | people = Herek, Stephen (Director) | title = Dead Like Me: Life After Death | url = https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1079444/ | medium = DVD | publisher = Metro Goldwyn Mayer | location = Montréal, Québec, Canada |date = 2009 }} [[List of Dead Like Me characters#George Lass|Georgia "George" Lass]] ([[Ellen Muth]]), the movie's narrator, is fired from Happy Time (a [[temporary work|temp agency]]) after she loudly chews out an employee for delivering a report late. The employee quits and later sues for harassment. George ends up revealing her identity to her sister [[List of Dead Like Me characters#Reggie Lass|Reggie]] ([[Britt McKillip]]). George finds herself reminiscing with Reggie, helping her prepare for the death of her boyfriend Hudson ([[Jordan Hudyma]]). Her fellow reapers confront Kane and learned that he had realized (and didn't care) that the "pebbles" of their misdeeds would cause "waves" of misfortune elsewhere. Unhappy with his style of management, they find themselves trying to figure out how exactly a fellow reaper can be killed as they shoot, drown, and finally dismember and cremate Kane. His ashes are then [[Space burial|shot into orbit]] along with those of [[List of Dead Like Me characters#Murray|Murray]], the cat belonging to George's boss [[List of Dead Like Me characters#Delores Herbig|Delores]]. At the launch, Delores tells George that the employee who had sued her for harassment had done so at several of the employee's previous jobs, and George is reinstated, now with a corner office. The reapers walk away from the launch, wondering who their new boss is; the movie closes with George who finds herself suddenly showered with [[Post-it note|Post-Its]] falling from the sky, like the Post-Its their former leader Rube had used to deliver their reaping assignments. Realizing she's been selected as the group's new leader, she says "I am so fucked" as the camera pulls away from the Earth into orbit. == Cast == *[[Ellen Muth]] as [[Georgia Lass]] *[[Callum Blue]] as [[Mason (Dead Like Me)|Mason]] *[[Sarah Wynter]] as [[Daisy Adair]] *[[Jasmine Guy]] as [[Roxy Harvey]] *[[Britt McKillip]] as [[Reggie Lass]] *[[Shenae Grimes]] as Jennifer Hardick *[[Christine Willes]] as [[List of Dead Like Me characters#Delores Herbig|Delores Herbig]] *[[Cynthia Stevenson]] as [[List of Dead Like Me characters#Joy Lass|Joy Lass]] *[[Henry Ian Cusick]] as Cameron Kane == Casting == In June 2007, a casting call was posted on an entertainment industry website for the role of [[Daisy Adair]], formerly played by [[Laura Harris]], who was unable to reprise the role due to commitments with ''[[Women's Murder Club (TV series)|Women's Murder Club]]''. It noted that [[John Masius]] wrote the film and also confirmed that [[Mandy Patinkin]], who starred in the original series, was not in the film. In August 2007, it was confirmed that [[Sarah Wynter]] would take over the role of [[Daisy Adair]] from Laura Harris. Harris and Wynter previously played sisters in the second season of ''[[24 (TV series)|24]]''. [[Henry Ian Cusick]] would play a new character named Cameron Kane.{{cite web|url=http://www.multichannel.com/blog/TV_Crush/7413-MGM_Resurrects_Dead_Like_Me.php |title=MGM Resurrects Dead Like Me |accessdate=August 8, 2007 |last=McNamara |first=Mary |date=August 6, 2007 |work=TV Crush |publisher=Multichannel News |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090131115727/http://www.multichannel.com/blog/TV_Crush/7413-MGM_Resurrects_Dead_Like_Me.php |archivedate=January 31, 2009 }} == Release == The film's release date was set for July 2008{{cite web|url=http://justpushplayonline.com/?m=200801 |title=So much going on! |access-date=March 27, 2008 |date=January 28, 2008 |publisher=Just Push Play |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080207085210/http://justpushplayonline.com/?p=304#comments |archive-date=February 7, 2008 }} and later rescheduled and released on February 17, 2009.{{cite web |url=http://videoeta.com/movie/109759 |access-date=November 16, 2008 |publisher=VideoETA.com |title=Dead Like Me: The Movie }} An exclusive television debut occurred on January 16, 2009 on [[Super Channel (Canada)|SuperChannel]] in [[Canada]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.channelcanada.com/Article2608.html |title=Dead Like Me – The Movie Coming to SuperChannel |date=January 13, 2009 |accessdate=February 20, 2011 |work=Channel Canada |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090416073641/http://channelcanada.com/Article2608.html |archive-date=April 16, 2009 }} It has also been shown in the [[United States]] on [[Syfy]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|1079444}} * {{AllMovie title|474764}} {{Dead Like Me}} {{Stephen Herek}} [[Category:2009 direct-to-video films]] [[Category:2000s comedy-drama films]] [[Category:2000s fantasy-comedy films]] [[Category:American comedy-drama films]] [[Category:American direct-to-video films]] [[Category:American fantasy-comedy films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Dead Like Me]] [[Category:Direct-to-video comedy films]] [[Category:Direct-to-video drama films]] [[Category:Direct-to-video fantasy films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Fantasy drama films]] [[Category:Films about death]] [[Category:Films based on television series]] [[Category:Films directed by Stephen Herek]] [[Category:Films set in Seattle]] [[Category:Films shot in Montreal]] [[Category:Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer direct-to-video films]]

{{DISPLAYTITLE:''Death Be Not Proud'' (book)}} {{Refimprove|date=September 2007}} {{Tone|date=March 2017}} [[File:DeathBeNotProud.jpg|thumb|First edition (publ. [[Harper & Brothers]])]] '''''Death Be Not Proud''''' is a 1949 memoir by American author [[John Gunther]], taking its name from [[s:Death be not proud|Holy Sonnet X]] by [[John Donne]]. The story was portrayed in a 1975 TV movie starring [[Robby Benson]] as Johnny Gunther and [[Arthur Hill (actor)|Arthur Hill]] as John Gunther.
==Story== In the book, Gunther records the true story of his teenage son's struggle to overcome a [[brain tumor]], and his ultimate death at 17. The story chronicles the period beginning when [[Johnny Gunther]] experiences the first symptoms of the tumor shortly after he had received a clean bill of health. Johnny's complaint of a stiff neck leads doctors to operate, which leads to the discovery of a tumor the size of an orange in his brain.
The book records, in simple detail, all the events and tensions in the months during which Johnny Gunther fought for his life, and his parents sought to help him through recourse to every medical treatment then known. After his last surgery, it was certain that the tumor was inoperable and had gone deep into his brain.
Both his parents knew the end of his life was near but still had plans for Johnny to spend his summer in the country. Even though no doctor gave him a chance of overcoming the tumor, Johnny was never told that he was dying
In the end, his death came quickly, as a result of the tumor rupturing a blood vessel in his brain. He died in a hospital, his parents at his side, at the age of 17, "like a thief death took him," his father writes. Johnny is described in his coffin movingly: "all that is left of a life!"
==Reception== Partly because of its stark honesty about the pain that the effects of the struggle on family at a time that cancer was a taboo subject, which was rarely talked about, and partly because of its refreshingly revealing portrait of a brilliant young man, who had discovered a new way to liquefy [[ammonia]], who was struck down too young by incurable illness, ''Death Be Not Proud'' became a best-selling book that is still popular today. The story was eventually made into a [[television movie]] in 1975, starring [[Robby Benson]] as Johnny Gunther, and [[Arthur Hill (actor)|Arthur Hill]] as his father.
==People== Johnny is an example of a truly valiant person. He is selfless in his hope that he will not cause too much pain for others. In Johnny's last few weeks on earth, he still hungers for knowledge. He does not give up because of his illness. He still has hopes and dreams intact.
His parents are also notable for the remarkable degree of communication and care they managed to share with each other and their son when his diagnosis was confirmed, and on to the end of his life. Although by the time of his diagnosis they had divorced and were living separately, they transcended distance, time, and whatever history had led them to separate in order to discuss carefully and kindly the options, care, and ongoing prognosis for his life.
Frances Gunther, his mother, takes care to have conversations with him about the ultimate issues of life and suffering as addressed in many cultures worldwide, making spiritual writings accessible to him and impressing on him the value of his thoughts and the effect of his actions on others.
Johnny's character is inspirational to not only his parents, but his caregivers as well, who employ sometimes radical treatments to try and save his life. Among them are Canadian neurosurgeon [[Wilder Penfield]] and [[Max Gerson|Dr. Max Gerson]], whose "Gerson diet" was used.
Wilder Penfield wrote a letter to his family after his death saying, "for such there must be an immortality which we who tinker at the body may guess at but not understand." <ref>''Wall Street Journal'' 01/26/08: W8</ref>
==Setting== ''Death Be Not Proud'' takes place in part in contemporary New York City, in the [[Neurological Institute of New York|Neurological Institute]], and at the [[Deerfield Academy]] where Johnny was a student, and at his mother's home in [[Connecticut]]. The Neurological institute rises tall above the [[Hudson River]] and the [[George Washington Bridge]]. Johnny Gunther, a cancer patient, stays in this hospital, on and off, during the last three years of his life. He also stays at the Gerson facility for a time. The family moves him to his mother's home in Connecticut when he is able, he visits his school briefly, to graduate with his class, then dies two weeks later.
==Theme(s)== The main theme of this book is how death and illness affect people, and how courage and a commitment to live fully in the face of daily discouragement and frequent setbacks transform such a life, however brief. During the fifteen months that Johnny had cancer, while going through many upheavals that most families do not experience, the Gunther family continued to be grateful he was still alive, and to celebrate that life. Although Johnny died at age 17, the Gunthers were grateful that he had survived as long as he had, and had continued to live as vibrantly and as intelligently as possible.
The title of the book, taken from Donne's poem, which ends with a comment on "the death of Death," summarizes this: Death had nothing to be proud of in Johnny's case. His (and his parents') wise, brave choices in living a brief life fully overcame any final destruction of the spirit that a fear of oncoming death might have otherwise wrought.
==John 'Papa' Gunther== The journalist, John Gunther, was a devoted father. John is the narrator of this heartbreaking story. He explains his beloved son’s battle with a brain tumor. He made sure to be with his son as often as possible, and to talk with him through his trials. John’s personality was quite subtle and he didn’t express his emotions.
==Johnny Gunther== John Gunther, Jr. (1929–1947) was an intelligent teenager living a life too soon aimed towards death. During his struggle with a brain tumor, Johnny studied on his own, received tutoring and took his school's proper exams, including college entrance. He did chemical experiments to follow up on ideas he developed even while ill. Though faced with death he continued to follow his dreams. Johnny was loved for his selflessness and his curiosity about life. He is portrayed throughout the memoir as a brilliant young man who tried with all his strength to defeat his brain tumor.
==Publication data== *John Gunther, ''Death Be Not Proud'' (1949). Harper Perennial edition 1998: {{ISBN|0-06-092989-8}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.bartleby.com/105/72.html Full text of Donne's poem, from bartleby.com] *{{imdb title|id=0072854|title=Death Be Not Proud}}

{{Infobox institute |name = DesignAge |image = |image_name = |image_size = |image_alt = |caption = |latin_name = |motto = |founder = |established = {{Start date|1991}} |mission = |focus = [[Inclusive design|Design]] for an [[aging|aging population]] |president = |chairman = |head_label = Director |head = [[Roger Coleman (professor)|Roger Coleman]] |faculty = |adjunct_faculty = |staff = |key_people = |budget = |endowment = |debt = |num_members = |subsidiaries = |owner = |non-profit_slogan = |former_name = |location = |city = [[London]] |state = |province = |country = [[UK]] |coor = |address = |website = {{URL|www.hhc.rca.ac.uk/archive/hhrc/programmes/designage}}{{dead link|date=June 2014}} |dissolved = {{End date|1999}} |footnotes = }} '''DesignAge''' was a cross-disciplinary<ref name=Queen>{{cite web|title=Previous Prize-winners|url=http://www.royalanniversarytrust.org.uk/the-prizes/previous-prize-winners?archive%5Bkeywords%5D=Royal+College+of+Art|publisher=The Royal Anniversary Trust|accessdate=25 September 2012}}</ref> [[action research]] programme within the [[Royal College of Art]] in the UK, founded in 1991 in partnership with the [[Helen Hamlyn Foundation]] to “explore the implications for design of ageing populations”<ref name=RSA1>[http://hhc.rca.ac.uk/resources/publications/RSA/RSA1.html "Breaking The Age Barrier"]. DesignAge. June 1997. Retrieved 11 October 2012.</ref> in the developed world. It was directed by [[Roger Coleman (professor)|Roger Coleman]] until 1999 when it was merged into the newly created [[Helen Hamlyn Research Centre]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hhc.rca.ac.uk/archive/hhrc/programmes/designage/index.html|title=DesignAge|publisher=The Helen Hamlyn Research Centre|accessdate=25 September 2012}}</ref><ref name=AARL>{{cite web|title=Age & Ability Research Lab – History|url=http://www.hhc.rca.ac.uk/290/all/1/history.aspx|publisher=Helen Hamlyn Research Centre|accessdate=25 September 2012}}</ref><ref name=RaisingOurGame>[http://www.designweek.co.uk/raising-our-game/3012575.article "Raising Our Game"]. ''Design Week''. Retrieved 26 September 2012.</ref> The programme was the recipient of the [[Queen's Anniversary Prize|Queen’s Anniversary Prize for Higher and Further Education]] in 1994 in the category of “the Arts”.<ref name="Queen"/>
==History== By the early 1990s, it was recognized that older adults, in particular adults over 50, were becoming an increasingly significant portion of the population, while improvements in nutrition and medicine were enabling these older adults to remain active. This demographic shift was thought to be permanent. However, the fact that the younger population represented a shrinking market and older population a growing one was largely ignored by the design profession. In response to the lack of understanding of these issues and the design community’s lack of understanding of their implications, in 1991 DesignAge was founded to investigate the needs of the older population, to interpret the results of the research in a way relevant to designers and industry, and to develop new methodologies in design and design education in response to this demographic shift.<ref name="RSA1"/><ref name=AboutDA>{{cite web|title=About DesignAge |url=http://designage.rca.ac.uk/DA/aboutDA.html |publisher=DesignAge |accessdate=23 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000819052351/http://designage.rca.ac.uk/da/aboutDA.html |archivedate=August 19, 2000 }}</ref>
DesignAge argued that older adults were [[Social model of disability|“rendered disabled” by]] public spaces and transportation systems that had not been designed for this segment of the population, and therefore design had an influential role to play in shaping the future, in that improvements of the life for older adults, as well as the job market and national economy could be realized if designers, manufacturers, and retailers could shift their attitudes towards aging so as to collaborate to create age-friendly products and services. By pointing out that designing for the aging population was designing for their own aging, effectively reframing aging as an issue of self-interest, DesignAge was able to engage younger designers to design for older people.<ref name=DesignResearchForOurFutureSelves>{{cite web|last=Coleman|first=Roger|title=Design Research for Our Future Selves|url=http://researchonline.rca.ac.uk/404/1/coleman_design_research_for_our_future_selves_1994.pdf|publisher=Royal College of Art|year=1994|accessdate=23 October 2012}}</ref><ref>Coleman, R.; Clarkson, J.; Dong, H.; Cassim, J. (2007). ''Design for Inclusivity''. Ashgate Publishing Company. p. 26</ref>
One of the ways that DesignAge used to engage design students was to hold an annual design competition, called the DesignAge Competition, held between 1992 and 1998, to challenge design students to design for their “future selves.”<ref>[http://www.hhc.rca.ac.uk/archive/hhrc/programmes/cp/competition/desage.html "The DesignAge Competition".] The Helen Hamlyn Research Centre. Retrieved 26 September 2012.</ref>
DesignAge also engaged the industry at large by approaching the [[Design Business Association]] (formed in 1986 by the [[Chartered Society of Designers]]<ref>[http://www.csd.org.uk/index.aspx?id=42 "Key Dates in CSD History"]. Chartered Society of Designers. Retrieved 26 September 2012.</ref>) and suggesting a “product challenge” to their member agencies; these were small-scale<ref>Cassim, Julia (April 2008). [http://www.dmi.org/dmi/html/conference/academic08/papers/Cassim/cassimj.pdf "The Challenge Workshop—a designer-friendly, cross-disciplinary knowledge transfer mechanism to promote innovative thinking in different contexts"]. International DMI Education Conference Design Thinking: New Challenges for Designers, Managers and Organizations 14–15 April 2008, ESSEC Business School, Cergy-Pointoise, France. Retrieved 26 September 2012.</ref> events where they would work with older users to design products on a speculative basis for the aging population.<ref name="RaisingOurGame"/>
In 1999 DesignAge became the Helen Hamlyn Research Centre and extended into the research of Inclusive Design.
==Selected publications== DesignAge produced a number of publications, including the seminal ''Designing For Our Future Selves'' published in 1993. Other publications include the “Designing for our future selves” special issue (volume 24, issue 1)<ref>{{cite web|title=Applied Ergonomics, Volume 24, Issue 1, Pages 2-69 (February 1993) – sciencedirect.com|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/journal/00036870/24/1|publisher=Elsevier B.V.|accessdate=23 October 2012}}</ref> of the journal ''Applied Ergonomics'' published in 1993; ''Once in a Lifetime: An Evaluation of Lifetime Homes in Hull,'' published in 1995; and ''Working Together, A New Approach To Design,'' published in 1997.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/19980111033134/http://designage.rca.ac.uk/DA/publications.html DesignAge Publications]. DesignAge. Retrieved 23 October 2012.</ref>
==Accomplishments== Within three years of its existence DesignAge reported that it was able to raise awareness of the issue within the design profession, in related disciplines including ergonomics, in education, and also among major retailers, manufacturers, and the age lobby.<ref name="DesignResearchForOurFutureSelves"/>
In 1994, DesignAge was awarded the Queen’s Anniversary Prize for Higher and Further Education in the category of “the Arts” in recognition of its contribution to the shift in perception towards designing for older adults and for working with corporations to design products for older adults and people incapacitated by illness.<ref name="Queen"/>
==Notable collaborations==
===Design for Ageing Network=== In 1994, DesignAge established a Europe-wide research network on design and aging called the DAN (Design for Ageing Network), funded until 1997 by [[Directorate-General for Employment, Social Affairs and Equal Opportunities (European Commission)|DG V]] of the European Commission (then the Directorate-General for Employment, Industrial Relations and Social Affairs<ref>[http://ec.europa.eu/bepa/european-group-ethics/archive-mandates/mandate-1991-1997/index_en.htm "Mandate 1991–1997"], European Commission. Retrieved 26 September 2012.</ref>). The network’s goal was to “develop the necessary expertise, know-how and understanding to enable design and industry to respond to the growing population of over-50’s in Europe in appropriate and life-enhancing ways” through the use of “in-depth collaboration with older people” that went “beyond simple measuring and questioning.”<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/19981206174133/http://dan.interact.nl/DAN/INFO/homepop1.html "What is the DAN?"]. Design for Ageing Network. Retrieved 23 October 2012.</ref>
After DesignAge was subsumed into the Helen Hamlyn Research Centre, DAN continued to exist until early 2004 when it was superseded by the Include Network.<ref>[http://www.hhc.rca.ac.uk/archive/hhrc/programmes/designage/DAN/index.html "The Design for Ageing Network"]. The Helen Hamlyn Research Centre. Retrieved 26 September 2012.</ref>
===Presence project=== DesignAge also participated in an EU-funded project called Presence,<ref name="AARL"/> which ran from 1997 to 1999<ref>[http://hookerandkitchen.com/presence/ The Presence Project]. Retrieved 11 October 2012.</ref> and whose aim was “enhancing activity and presence of older people in communities”.<ref>[http://www.presenceweb.i3net.org/ Presence]. Presence. Retrieved 11 October 2012.</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://www.hhc.rca.ac.uk/archive/hhrc/programmes/designage/index.html Official archived website]

'''Fan-funded music''' is a type of [[crowdfunding]] that specifically pertains to [[music]].[https://www.wired.com/listening_post/2008/03/review-slicethe/ Eliot Van Buskirk, "SlicethePie Unleashes Its First Fan-Funded Album", Wired, 10 March 2008] Often, fan-funded music occurs in conjunction with direct-to-fan marketing.Chaney, D. (2010). What future for fan-funded labels in the music recording industry? The cases of MyMajorCompany and ArtistShare. International Journal of Arts Management, 12(2), 44-48. Fans of music have the option to donate and collectively raise money with the goal of jump-starting the career of a given musical artist. The fan-funding of music occurs primarily through web-based services using a [[Comparison of crowd funding services#Crowdfunding models|business model for crowdfunding]]. Fans are typically given rewards based on their monetary contributions. ==Notable platforms== {| style="width:50%; text-align: center;" class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Website !! Year
of
Launch !! Notes |- | [[ArtistShare|ArtistShare.com]] ||2000 || First crowdfunding site for music |- | [[Indiegogo|Indiegogo.com]] ||2008||Disburses funds immediately |- | [[Kickstarter|Kickstarter.com]] || 2009|| Takes 5% flat fee, Stripe takes additional 3-5% |- | [[Patreon|Patreon.com]] || 2013 || Enables fans to support and engage with artists and creators |- | [[PledgeMusic|Pledgemusic.com]] || 2009 ||Can donate profits to charity. International. |- | [[Rocket Fuel|Rocketfuelhq.com]] || 2014 || Takes 5-10%. Based in UK. |- | [[RocketHub|Rockethub.com]] || 2010 || Takes 8% total funds accumulated. No screening process. |- | [[Sellaband|Sellaband.com]] ||2006 || Currency in [[€]]. Partners with [[Soundcloud]]. |} ===Additional information=== '''[[ArtistShare|ArtistShare.com]]'''
ArtistShare is documented as being the first fan-funded website for music.[http://knowledge.wharton.upenn.edu/article.cfm?articleid=2647 “Can You Spare a Quarter? Crowdfunding Sites Turn Fans into Patrons of the Arts”]. Wharton Innovation and Entrepreneurship. December 8, 2010. Retrieved November 20, 2012. The service lets musicians fund their projects utilizing a "fan-funding" model. In exchange for funding on a particular project, contributors receive various benefits. ArtistShare emphasizes on their website that for each project, the artist is in no way required to relinquish ownership of copyright, as this model is not a [[Work for hire|work made for hire]].[https://www.artistshare.com/v4/Home/About ArtistShare -- About Us]. Retrieved on November 20, 2012. '''[[Indiegogo|Indiegogo.com]]'''
Indiegogo is a [[Crowd funding]] portal that allows users to create a page for their funding campaign, set up an account with [[PayPal]], make a list of "perks" for different levels of donation, then create a [[social media]]-based publicity effort. Users publicize the projects themselves through [[Facebook]], [[Twitter]] and similar platforms. The site takes a 4% fee for successful campaigns. For campaigns that fail to raise their target amount, users have the option of either refunding all money to their contributors at no charge or keeping all money raised minus a 9% fee.{{cite web |url= http://www.indiegogo.com/learn/pricing |title= Learn More |publisher= Indiegogo |accessdate= 2012-06-16}} Unlike similar sites such as [[Kickstarter]], Indiegogo disburses the funds immediately, when the contributions are collected through the user's PayPal accounts. Indiegogo also offers direct credit card payment acceptance through their own portal. Those funds are disbursed up to two weeks after the conclusion of a campaign.{{cite news | first = Sarah | last = Needleman | title = When 'Friending' Becomes a Source of Start-Up Funds | date = November 1, 2011 | url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204528204577007781568296346?mod=googlenews_wsj | work = Wall Street Journal | accessdate = 2011-12-05}} '''[[Kickstarter|Kickstarter.com]]'''
Often hailed as the most successful and well-known [[Crowd funding]] platform. Kickstarter has been featured on [[CNN]], [[NYT|The New York Times]], [[TIME|TIME magazine]], [[BBC]] and [[WIRED|Wired Magazine]]. Kickstarter is a [[Crowd funding]] website that has successfully funded everything from films, games, and music to art, design, and technology. Project creators choose a deadline and a goal minimum of funds to raise. If the chosen goal is not gathered by the deadline, no funds are collected. The platform is open to backers from anywhere in the world and to creators from the US or the UK. Kickstarter takes a 5% fee and [[Amazon.com]] takes an additional 3%. '''[[PledgeMusic|PledgeMusic.com]]'''
PledgeMusic is an international [[Crowd funding]] platform geared specifically toward musicians. Users (Pledgers) receive exclusive content in exchange for their contributions to artists fundraising campaigns. PledgeMusic does not retain any ownership or rights to any music created through the platform. Funding transactions occur only after a goal is successfully met. The site is staffed my music industry moguls and maintains partnerships with major players in the digital and physical music spheres allowing for numerous options to help record, produce, manufacture, market, and distribute artist's music, merchandise, and tickets. The site charges a 15% flat fee.[http://www.pledgemusic.com/site/about PledgeMusic.com -- about]. Retrieved November 27, 2012. PledgeMusic operates on two types of artist campaigns, [[direct-to-fan]] and a Pre-order campaign. In a pre-order campaign, fans are charged immediately upon pledging. This type of campaign is designed for labels and artists who have already completed a recording, and are looking for a strategic way to pre-sell and market it.[http://www.pledgemusic.com/site/faq PledgeMusic.com -- FAQ]. Retrieved November 26, 2012. '''[[RocketHub|RocketHub.com]]'''
Rocket Hub is an established [[crowd funding]] platform open to anyone including musicians. Project holders on Rocket Hub have the option to keep raised proceeds even if the fundraising pledge was not successful. Rocket Hub is a completely open platform, meaning that anyone can create a fan-funding campaign and there is no screening process before the project goes live. The site takes an 8% commission off successful projects.[http://www.musicthinktank.com/blog/the-musicians-guide-to-fan-funding.html Ostrow, Jonathan -- Musician's guide to Fan-Funded Music -- August 16th, 2010]. Retrieved November 27th, 2012. '''[[Sellaband|Sellaband.com]]'''
Sellaband is a [[crowd funding]] platform that allows registered Artists to use a [[direct-to-fan]] approach to finance albums or concerts.[https://www.sellaband.com/en/pages/how_it_works_artists Sellaband.com -- How it Works -- Artists.] Retrieved November 27, 2012. Artists will pledge an amount, the minimum funding target being [[€]] 3000, and the maximum funding target, €250.000. Artists may also choose if they want to integrate a [[revenue sharing]] option into their funding. The minimum incentive is a download.{{cite web|url=https://www.sellaband.com/believer/new#artist|title=Sellaband - Join SellaBand|author=SellaBand|work=SellaBand}} ==Cases of note== ===Marillion=== The British rock band [[Marillion]] are considered to be one of the first artists to have truly harnessed the power of the [[internet]] as a means of music distribution and direct contact with fans, which began with setting up a website in 1996 and raising $60,000 to help finance a 1997 North American tour.{{cite news | url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/music/1325340.stm | title= Marillion fans to the rescue | first=Tim |last=Masters | work=BBC News | date=2001-05-11}} They have also been described by ''[[The Guardian]]'' music journalist [[Alexis Petridis]] as "the undisputed pioneers" of the fan-funded music model,{{cite news | url= https://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/apr/18/popandrock.alexispetridis | title= This song was brought to you by ... | work=The Guardian | first=Alexis | last=Petridis | date=18 April 2008 | accessdate=16 June 2015}} beginning with the distribution of their 2001 release ''[[Anoraknophobia]]''. Amidst a dissolving relationship with their record label and management team, the band calculated that they would need 5,000 fans to order the album to finance the project. However, they needed the money up-front, before the record was released. They turned to their mailing list and asked fans to pre-order the album in what was later described by the [[BBC]] as "a unique funding campaign". Pre-sales well exceeded their 5,000-unit target (reaching about 12,000 pre-sales total).[http://www.music4point5.com/blog/the-marillion-story-and-what-we-can-all-learn-from-it/ The Marillion story and what we can all learn from it - Music 4.5] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121109142548/http://www.music4point5.com/blog/the-marillion-story-and-what-we-can-all-learn-from-it/ |date=2012-11-09 }} Marillion have since released several other albums based on a fan-funded model, receiving a £360,000 advance for their 15th studio album ''[[Happiness Is the Road]]''. ===Amanda Palmer=== Unofficially dubbed the "queen" of Kickstarter, [[Amanda Palmer]] is an example of one of the most successful fan-funded music campaigns of all time. On April 30, 2012, Palmer ran a campaign on Kickstarter, with a goal of $100,000 to fund her newest studio album, ''[[Theatre Is Evil]]''. By the end of May 2012, Palmer had amassed almost $1.2 million, ultimately receiving donations from nearly 25,000 individuals.{{cite web|url=http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/amandapalmer/amanda-palmer-the-new-record-art-book-and-tour|title=Amanda Palmer: The new RECORD, ART BOOK, and TOUR|work=Kickstarter}} By comparison, the average successful project on Kickstarter at the time raised about $5,000.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/06/arts/music/amanda-palmer-takes-connecting-with-her-fans-to-a-new-level.html | work=The New York Times | first=Ben | last=Sisario | title=Amanda Palmer Takes Connecting With Her Fans to a New Level | date=June 5, 2012}} ===Ellis Paul=== Boston-based singer/songwriter [[Ellis Paul]] is another important case study in the field of fan-funded music. His 2010 release, The Day After Everything Changed, was funded completely by fan donations. Instead of using a traditional crowd-funding platform, he adapted the online merchandise platform [[Nimbit]] to his own fan-funding scheme. Paul set up a tiered donation hierarchy, ranging from the $15 Street Busker level, up to the $10,000 Woody Guthrie level.{{cite web|url=http://ellispaul.com/index.php?page=news&display=2339|title=ELLIS PAUL|date=9 July 2008|work=Ellis Paul}} Fans received different perks based on the tier at which they donated. The project proved to be highly successful, with total donations exceeding $100,000.{{cite web|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/music/articles/2009/04/12/lighters_down_checkbooks_up/|title=Musicians and fans join together to get albums made - The Boston Globe|work=boston.com}} Paul is putting his fan-funding to the test again; he is currently in the midst of fan-funding a new studio album set to release sometime in 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.ellispaul.com/index.php?page=blog&category=&display=5695|title=ELLIS PAUL|date=26 September 2012|work=Ellis Paul}} ===Electric Eel Shock=== [[Tokyo]]-based [[garage rock|garage]] [[heavy metal music|metal]] band [[Electric Eel Shock]] is another group that has seen some success in the way of fan-funded music. In 2004 they offered a "SAMURAI 100" package, which gave fans the opportunity to secure "guest list for life" status. The package cost £100 and the band raised £10,000 by selling 100 such packages.{{cite web|url=http://drownedinsound.com/news/10764-wanna-go-vip-electric-eel-shock-ll-show-you-the-way|title=Wanna Go VIP? Electric Eel Shock'll show you the way...|work=DrownedInSound}} ==Criticism== As a business practice, fan-funded music is not without its criticism. Fan-funded music has gained popularity in the past few years however, money raised through these platforms still is only estimated to make up 1% of the amount spent on albums and tours. Many bands start off with fan funding to finance their initial album but then get signed to a record label. Major labels are signing artists with successful fan funded campaigns using the campaigns as a filter before investing in them.{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2010/jan/21/fan-funded-model-record-deal | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Helienne | last=Lindvall | title=Behind the music: The fan-funded model that led to a major record deal | date=January 21, 2010}} Other, more well-known bands have used fan funding to distance themselves from their label contracts and manage their own music. There has yet to be a band that has used fan funding to fully finance their career.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-18788054 | work=BBC News | title=How fan-funding is changing the face of music finance | date=July 12, 2012}} In 2001, ''The Guardian'' journalist [[Gareth McLean]] was scathing of Marillion's pioneering efforts to continue their career without a label by dealing directly with their fans on the Internet, writing: "They have, they explained, decided to eschew the machinations of the record industry in order to be closer to the people. (One suspects that their decision occurred round about the time that the record industry decided to shun Marillion)."{{cite web | url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/2001/aug/13/tvandradio.television1 | title= In the realm of pretences| author=Gareth McLean| date=13 August 2001|work=The Guardian |location=UK}} Some claim that artists overestimate the cost of recording an album and dishonestly solicit more money than they need via fan-funding.{{cite web|url=http://www.musicthinktank.com/blog/an-argument-against-fan-funding.html|title=An Argument Against Fan Funding - MTT - Music Think Tank|work=musicthinktank.com}} With advancements in digital technology, recording equipment has become increasingly compact and more affordable. It is no longer a requirement for an artist to need a large recording studio that houses oversized equipment. This increase in accessibility that the everyday musician has today has made it possible for artists to record their own albums from their homes. Since there are no restrictions for what artists can ask for, it is not unheard of for artists to inflate the expected costs and then keep the extra money as profit. Critics also point out that the fan-funded music model has turned bands into marketers and sales personnel. Artists must be able to develop personal marketing strategies in order to get the money to even begin working on their music.{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/blog/index.php?blog=10&title=the_problem_with_fan_funded_music&more=1&c=1&tb=1&pb=1|title=The Problem With Fan-Funded Music|author=NME.COM|work=nme.com}} Artists must put lots of time and effort into creating a campaign that engages their fans and gets them to donate to their project. This can prove difficult for any artist to create a campaign that does not come off as "[a] shrill and desperate-modern-day pan-handling by entitled go-getters."{{citation needed|date=February 2015}} While fan-funded platforms are accessible for any musician, they have become over-crowded with both artists and anyone with an idea. "For every legitimately exciting pitch there are dozens of musicians, filmmakers and designers pleading for funds to complete ill-conceived projects."{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10000872396390443991704577579190431157610|title=The Good, the Bad and the Crowdfunded|author=Erik Sofge|date=18 August 2012|work=WSJ}} Running fan-funded campaigns cost bands a large sum of money. They must pay for video production for the video that every campaign has,{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} a producer and an engineer to mix and master their album, and fulfill all of the rewards promised to their fans as well as the shipping on them. Often the money made off these projects ends up going to paying the costs of running a successful fan funded campaign. For example, a large portion of the $1 million that [[Amanda Palmer]] raised went into funding her [[Kickstarter]] project itself.{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/therecord/2012/11/23/165658174/how-much-does-crowdfunding-cost-musicians|title=How Much Does Crowd Funding Cost Musicians?|date=23 November 2012|work=NPR.org}} Artists such as Palmer have huge fan bases to appeal to for money, but for the average artist raising that kind of money isn't a reliable method.{{cite web|url=http://www.musicclout.com/contents/article-116-why-i-hate-crowd-funding-by-normandie-wilson.aspx|title=Music Clout|work=musicclout.com}} ==See also== * [[Crowd funding]] * [[Comparison of crowd funding services]] * [[Direct-to-fan]] * [[Freemium]] * [[Free-to-play]] * [[Kickstarter]] * [[Open Music Model]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} [[Category:Music industry]] [[Category:Crowdfunding]]

[[File:Flaubert-Giraud.jpg|thumb|Flaubert at about the age of 50. Portrait by [[Eugène Giraud]]]] The '''letters of Gustave Flaubert''', the 19th-century French novelist, range in date from 1829, when he was 7 or 8 years old, to a day or two before his death in 1880.{{cite web |url=http://flaubert.univ-rouen.fr/jet/public/correspondance/feuilletage_liste_elts.php?t=C |title=Présentation des lettres par ordre chronologique |editor1-last=Leclerc |editor1-first=Yvan |editor2-last=Girard |editor2-first=Danielle |date=2 November 2017 |website=Correspondence: Édition électronique |publisher=Centre Flaubert, Université de Rouen |language=French |access-date=2 August 2018 }} They are considered one of the finest bodies of letters in French literature, admired even by many who are critical of [[Gustave Flaubert|Flaubert]]'s novels.{{sfn|Barnes|2003}} His main correspondents include family members, business associates and fellow-writers such as [[Théophile Gautier]], the [[Goncourt brothers]], [[Guy de Maupassant]], [[Charles Augustin Sainte-Beuve]], [[George Sand]], [[Ivan Turgenev]] and [[Émile Zola]]. They provide a valuable glimpse of his methods of work and his literary philosophy, as well as documenting his social life, political opinions, and increasing disgust with bourgeois society. == Correspondents == 4481 letters by Flaubert survive,{{sfn|Leclerc|Girard|2017}} a number which would have been considerably higher but for a series of burnings of his letters to his friends. Many of those addressed to [[Maxime Du Camp]], [[Guy de Maupassant]] and [[Louis Bouilhet]] were destroyed in this way.{{cite book |last1=Porter |first1=Laurence M. |last2=Gray |first2=Eugene F. |year=2002 |title=Gustave Flaubert's ''Madame Bovary'': A Reference Guide |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=T_BcAAAAMAAJ&q=%22most+of+his+letters+to+and+from+his+close+friends%22&dq=%22most+of+his+letters+to+and+from+his+close+friends%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiot9SCn87cAhXLyaQKHUWuCR8Q6AEIJzAA |location=Westport, Conn. |publisher=Greenwood Press |page=145 |isbn=0313319162 |access-date=2 August 2018 }} From those that survive it appears that his principal correspondents were as follows.{{cite web |url=http://flaubert.univ-rouen.fr/jet/public/correspondance/feuilletage_liste_elts.php?corpus=correspondance |title=Présentation des lettres par destinataire |editor1-last=Leclerc |editor1-first=Yvan |editor2-last=Girard |editor2-first=Danielle |date=2 November 2017 |website=Correspondence: Édition électronique |publisher=Centre Flaubert, Université de Rouen |language=French |access-date=2 August 2018 }} His family members:
{{columns-list|colwidth=25em| * Anne Justine Caroline Flaubert, his mother * Caroline Hamard, his sister * Caroline Commanvile, his niece * Ernest Commanville, his niece's husband }} His friends, associates and readers:
{{columns-list|colwidth=25em| * [[Agénor Bardoux]], politician * Princesse [[Mathilde Bonaparte]], niece of [[Napoleon|Napoleon I]], cousin of [[Napoleon III]], literary patron * [[Amélie Bosquet]] ([[:fr:Amélie Bosquet|FR]]), feminist writer * Louis Bouilhet, poet and friend of Flaubert from childhood * Marie-Louise Léonie Brainne (née Rivière), journalist * Maxime Du Camp, journalist, photographer and travelling companion of Flaubert * [[Marie-Sophie Leroyer de Chantepie]] ([[:fr:Marie-Sophie Leroyer de Chantepie|FR]]), minor novelist * [[Georges Charpentier]], publisher * [[Ernest Chevalier]] ([[:fr:Ernest Chevalier|FR]]), judge and friend from childhood * [[Louise Colet]], poet and Flaubert's lover * Jules Duplan, businessman * [[Ernest-Aimé Feydeau]], writer * Frédéric Fovard, notary * [[Théophile Gautier]], poet and writer * Edma Roger des Genettes, literary and artistic ''salonnière'' * [[Edmond de Goncourt|Edmond]] and [[Jules de Goncourt]], novelists and diarists * Edmond Laporte, local politician and businessman * [[Alphonse Lemerre]], publisher * Philippe Leparfait, adopted son of Louis Bouilhet * [[Michel Lévy]], publisher * Guy de Maupassant, short-story writer * [[Claudius Popelin]] ([[:fr:Claudius Popelin|FR]]), painter, writer and sometime lover of Princesse Mathilde Bonaparte * [[Edgar Raoul-Duval]], politician * [[Charles Augustin Sainte-Beuve]], critic and novelist * [[George Sand]], novelist * [[Hippolyte Taine]], writer on art and literature * [[Gertrude Tennant]], English society hostess * [[Marie-Anne Detourbay|Jeanne de Tourbey]], successful ''[[Demimonde|demi-mondaine]]'' * Jules Troubat, Sainte-Beuve's secretary * [[Ivan Turgenev]], Russian novelist * [[Émile Zola]], novelist{{sfn|Steegmuller|1954|pp=56–57}}{{cite news |last=Flood |first=Alison |date=27 July 2009 |title=Letters Reveal Flaubert's English 'Amitié Amoureuse' |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2009/jul/27/flaubert-amitie-amoureuse-letters |work=The Guardian |location=London |access-date=2 August 2018 }}{{cite book |year=1980 |editor1-last=Steegmuller |editor1-first=Francis |title=The Letters of Gustave Flaubert 1830–1857 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=srZfwgWpQysC&pg=PA222&dq=%22contract+with+the+publisher+Michel%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiemcfFqs7cAhVrCsAKHQTdAJAQ6AEIOTAD#v=onepage&q=%22contract%20with%20the%20publisher%20Michel%22&f=false |location=Cambridge, Mass. |publisher=Belknap Press of the Harvard University Press |page=222 |isbn=0674526368 |access-date=2 August 2018 }}{{sfn|Steegmuller|1982|pp=5, 18, 65 108, 133, 195, 219, 250, 251}}{{sfn|Winock|2016|pp=230, 312}}{{cite book |year=1969 |editor1-last=Thorlby |editor1-first=Anthony |title=The Penguin Companion to Literature. 2: European |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=sIWnIOCXU7AC&q=%22French+critic+and+novelist+early%22&dq=%22French+critic+and+novelist+early%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjNtNDirc7cAhXKa8AKHa6NBxMQ6AEIKzAB |location=Harmondsworth |publisher=Penguin |pages=304, 686 |isbn=9780140510355 |access-date=2 August 2018 }} }} == Themes == Flaubert's personality was rigorously excluded from his novels, but in the letters, written at night after the day's literary work was done, he expresses much more spontaneously his own personal views.{{sfn|Steegmuller|1954|p=11}} Their themes often arise from his life as a reader and writer. They discuss the subject-matter and structural difficulties of his novels, and explore the problems Flaubert faced in their composition, giving the reader a unique glimpse of his art in the making.{{sfn|Lloyd|2004|p=76}} They illustrate his extensive reading of the creative literatures of France, England (he loved [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]], [[Lord Byron|Byron]] and [[Charles Dickens|Dickens]]), Germany and the classical world; also his deep researches into history, philosophy and the sciences.{{sfn|Le Calvez|2001|p=74}}{{sfn|Barnes|2002|p=244}} Above all, they constantly state and restate Flaubert's belief in the duty of the writer to maintain his independence, and in his own need to reach literary beauty through a quasi-scientific objectivity.{{sfn|Steegmuller|1954|pp=17–18}}{{sfn|Le Calvez|2001|p=75}}{{cite news |last=Hampshire |first=Stuart |author-link=Stuart Hampshire |date=16 December 1982 |title=In Flaubert's Laboratory |url=https://www.nybooks.com/articles/1982/12/16/in-flauberts-laboratory/ |work=The New York Review of Books |access-date=2 August 2018 }} But his letters also demonstrate an enjoyment of the simple pleasures of Flaubert's youth. Friendship, love, conversation, a delight in foreign travel, the pleasures of the table and of the bed are all in evidence.{{sfn|Lloyd|2004|p=67}}{{cite book |last1=Vidal |first1=Gore |author-link1=Gore Vidal |year=1982 |title=Pink Triangle and Yellow Star, and Other Essays (1976–1982) |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=xDQgAQAAIAAJ&q=%22brothels+and+baths+of%22&dq=%22brothels+and+baths+of%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjul5S1l8_cAhXIK8AKHR8tD68Q6AEIQzAF |location=London |publisher=Heinemann |page=29 |isbn=9780434830756 |access-date=2 August 2018 }} These do not disappear in his maturer years, but they are offset by discussions of politics and current affairs which reveal an increasing disgust with society, especially bourgeois society, and with the age he lived in.{{cite book |last1=Lloyd |first1=Rosemary |year=2014 |orig-year=1990 |title=Madame Bovary |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=0F4tBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA21&dq=%22flaubert's+letters%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi3jIb9hK3aAhVlKsAKHdNpAMY4FBDoAQg-MAU#v=onepage&q=%22flaubert's%20letters%22&f=false |location=Abingdon |publisher=Routledge |page=21 |isbn=9781138799349 |access-date=2 August 2018 }}{{sfn|Le Calvez|2001|p=74}} They exude a sadness and a sense of having grown old before his time.{{sfn|Lloyd|2004|p=80}} As a whole, said the literary critic Eric Le Calvez, Flaubert's correspondence, "reveals his vision of life and of the relation between life and art: since the human condition is miserable, life can be legitimated only through an eternal pursuit of art."{{sfn|Le Calvez|2001|p=74}} == Critical reception == [[File:Flaubert letter.jpg|thumb|An 1877 letter from [[Gustave Flaubert]] to [[Léon Cladel]]]] For many years after the first publication of the letters critical opinion was divided. [[Albert Thibaudet]] thought them "the expression of a first-rate intellect", and [[André Gide]] wrote that "For more than five years his correspondence took the place of the Bible at my bedside. It was my reservoir of energy". [[Frank Harris]] said that in his letters "he lets himself go and unconsciously paints himself for us to the life; and this Gustave Flaubert is enormously more interesting than anything in ''Madame Bovary''".{{cite book |last1=Harris |first1=Frank |author-link1=Frank Harris |year=1927 |title=Latest Contemporary Portraits |location=New York |publisher=Macaulay |page=206 }} On the other hand [[Marcel Proust]] found Flaubert's epistolary style "even worse" than that of his novels, while for [[Henry James]] the Flaubert of the letters was "impossible as a companion".{{sfn|Steegmuller|1982|pp=xvii–xviii}} This ambivalence is a thing of the past, and there is now widespread agreement that the Flaubert correspondence is one of the finest in French literature.{{sfn|Le Calvez|2001|p=74}} Publication of them "has crowned his reputation as the exemplary artist".{{cite web |url=http://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/acref/9780192806871.001.0001/acref-9780192806871-e-2807?rskey=3k4M21&result=4 |title=The Oxford Companion to English Literature (7 ed.) |date=2009 |editor-last=Birch |editor-first=Dinah |editor-link=Dinah Birch |website=Oxford Reference |publisher=Oxford University Press |access-date=2 August 2018 }} [[Enid Starkie]] wrote that Flaubert was one of his own greatest literary creations, and that the letters might well be seen in the future as his greatest book, and the one in which "he has most fully distilled his personality and his wisdom".{{cite book |last1=Starkie |first1=Enid |year=1971 |title=Flaubert the Master: A Critical and Biographical Study (1856-1880) |location=London |publisher=Weidenfeld and Nicolson |pages=355-356 |isbn=0297002260 }} [[Jean-Paul Sartre]], an inveterate enemy of Flaubert's novels, considered the letters a perfect example of pre-Freudian [[Free association (psychology)|free association]], and for [[Julian Barnes]] this description "hints at their fluency, profligacy, range and sexual frankness; to which we should add power, control, wit, emotion and furious intelligence. The ''Correspondance''...has always added up to Flaubert's best biography."{{sfn|Barnes|2002|p=239}}{{sfn|Barnes|2003}} Rosemary Lloyd analyses the elements of their appeal as being "partly [their] wide sweep, partly the sense of seeing what Baudelaire called the strings and pulleys of the writer's workshop, and partly the immediacy of Flaubert's changeable, complex and challenging personality." She continues, "Reading Flaubert's correspondence brings startlingly alive a man of enormous complexity, of remarkable appetites and debilitating lethargies, a knotted network of prejudices, insights, blind spots, passions and ambitions."{{sfn|Lloyd|2004|pp=67, 83}} == Editions == * {{cite book |last1=Flaubert |first1=Gustave |year=1887–1893 |title=Correspondance |location=Paris |publisher=G. Charpentier }} This four-volume edition was the first to try to collect Flaubert's letters. The unnamed editor was Flaubert's niece Caroline Commanville; she censored the letters freely, cutting out many passages which she thought indecent or which referred unflatteringly to living persons, especially to herself, and very often failing to notify the reader of these cuts by the use of [[Ellipsis|ellipses]]. She also corrected his punctuation and sometimes "improved" his phrasing.{{sfn|Lloyd|2004|p=68}}{{sfn|Steegmuller|1982|pp=xv–xvi}}{{sfn|Barnes|2003}}{{sfn|Cléroux|2013}} * {{cite book |last1=Flaubert |first1=Gustave |year=1910 |title=Correspondance |location=Paris |publisher=Conard }} A five-volume edition which has been described as "seriously flawed".{{sfn|Winock|2016|p=422}}{{sfn|Cléroux|2013}} * {{cite book |year=1922–1925 |editor1-last=Descharmes |editor1-first=René |title=Correspondance |location=Paris |publisher=Librairie de France }} In four volumes. The first scholarly edition.{{sfn|Winock|2016|p=422}}{{sfn|Cléroux|2013}} * {{cite book |last1=Flaubert |first1=Gustave |title=Correspondance |location=Paris |publisher=Louis Conard }} In nine volumes, containing 1992 letters. Most of the notes were taken from René Descharmes' edition.{{sfn|Le Calvez|2001|p=75}}{{sfn|Cléroux|2013}} * {{cite book |year=1954 |editor1-last=Dumesnil |editor1-first=René |editor1-link=René Dumesnil |editor2-last=Pommier |editor2-first=Jean |editor3-last=Digeon |editor3-first=Claude |title=Correspondance: Supplément |location=Paris |publisher=Louis Conard, Jacques Lambert }} Adds 1296 letters to the edition of 1926–1933.{{sfn|Le Calvez|2001|p=75}}{{sfn|Cléroux|2013}} * {{cite book |year=1973–2007 |editor1-last=Bruneau |editor1-first=Jean |title=Correspondance |series=Bibliothèque de la Pléiade |location=Paris |publisher=Gallimard }} In five volumes, the first four edited by Jean Bruneau, and the fifth, which was published after Bruneau's death, co-edited with [[Yvan Leclerc]] ([[:fr:Yvan Leclerc|FR]]). This edition boasts an extremely thorough critical apparatus, with letters written to Flaubert, excerpts from the [[Goncourt Journal]] and other third-party documentation, together with explanatory and critical notes by the editor. Julian Barnes points out that in the third volume the appendices, notes and variants take up more pages than the letters themselves.{{cite news |last=Barnes |first=Julian |date=14 March 2008 |title=The Lost Governess |url=https://www.the-tls.co.uk/articles/public/julian-barnes-gustave-flaubert/ |work=TLS |location=London |access-date=3 August 2018 }}{{sfn|Barnes|2003}}{{sfn|Cléroux|2013}} * {{cite book |year=1974–1976 |editor1-last=Bardèche |editor1-first=Maurice |editor1-link=Maurice Bardèche |title=Correspondance |location=Paris |publisher=Club de l'Honnête Homme }} In five volumes.{{sfn|Cléroux|2013}} * {{cite book |year=2001 |editor1-last=Bonaccorso |editor1-first=Giovanni |title=Correspondance. Première édition scientifique |location=Saint-Genouph |publisher=Nizet }} Two volumes were published, taking the edition up to 1861, but the editor's death brought the project to a halt.{{sfn|Cléroux|2013}} * {{cite web |url=http://flaubert.univ-rouen.fr/correspondance/edition/ |title=Correspondance: Édition électronique |editor1-last=Leclerc |editor1-first=Yvan |editor2-last=Girard |editor2-first=Danielle |date=2 November 2017 |website=Correspondence de Flaubert |publisher=Centre Flaubert, Université de Rouen |access-date=29 July 2018 }} A freely available Web-based edition comprising 4481 letters, 134 of which have not previously been published.{{sfn|Leclerc|Girard|2017}}{{cite web |url=http://flaubert.univ-rouen.fr/jet/public/correspondance/feuilletage.php?t=I |title=Correspondance de Flaubert - Lettres Inédites |editor1-last=Leclerc |editor1-first=Yvan |editor2-last=Girard |editor2-first=Danielle |date=2 November 2017 |website=Correspondence: Édition électronique |publisher=Centre Flaubert, Université de Rouen |access-date=3 August 2018 }} There have also been many single-correspondent editions of Flaubert's letters to one or another of his friends and associates, and selections from the collected letters.{{sfn|Cléroux|2013}} == Translations == * {{cite book |last1=Tarver |first1=John Charles |year=1895 |title=Gustave Flaubert: As Seen in his Works and Correspondence |location=Westminster |publisher=A. Constable }} The first selection of the letters in English.{{sfn|Winock|2016|p=517}}{{cite web |url=https://scholarworks.uno.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1086&context=engl_facpubs |title=The Hermit of Croisset: Flaubert's Fiercely Enduring Perfectionism |last=Goodman |first=Richard |date=2009 |website=English Faculty Publications |publisher=University of New Orleans |page=4 |format=PDF |access-date=3 August 2018 }} * {{cite book |translator-last1=Mckenzie |translator-first1=Aimée L. |year=1922 |title=The George Sand – Gustave Flaubert Letters |location=London |publisher=Duckworth }}{{cite book |last1=Massardier-Kenney |first1=Françoise |author-link1=Françoise Massardier-Kenney |year=2000 |title=Gender in the Fiction of George Sand |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=p2BQq6dskAoC&pg=PA188&dq=%22flaubert+letters+london+duckworth%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjlnKOaydHcAhURLFAKHcFND6oQ6AEILTAB#v=onepage&q=%22flaubert%20letters%20london%20duckworth%22&f=false |location=Amsterdam |publisher=Rodopi |page=188 |isbn=9042007079 |access-date=3 August 2018 }} * {{cite book |translator-last1=Cohen |translator-first1=J. M. |translator-link1=J. M. Cohen |year=1950 |editor1-last=Rumbold |editor1-first=Richard |title=Gustave Flaubert: Letters |location=London |publisher=Weidenfeld and Nicolson }} Includes 122 letters.{{cite journal |last1=Cranston |first1=Maurice |author-link1=Maurice Cranston |date=12 May 1950 |title=Flaubert's Letters |url=http://archive.spectator.co.uk/article/12th-may-1950/26/flauberts-letters |journal=The Spectator |page=26 |access-date=29 July 2018 }} * {{cite book |year=1954 |editor1-last=Steegmuller |editor1-first=Francis |editor1-link=Francis Steegmuller |title=The Selected Letters of Gustave Flaubert |location=London |publisher=Hamish Hamilton }} According to ''[[The Nation]]'', Steegmuller "edited them with discretion after translating them with authority".{{cite book |year=1977 |editor1-last=Sypher |editor1-first=F. J. |title=The Reader's Adviser: A Layman's Guide to Literature. Volume 2 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=NXg0AAAAMAAJ&q=%22epistolary+literature+and+Francis%22&dq=%22epistolary+literature+and+Francis%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjXk-Cs7NHcAhXKKcAKHXQyB1IQ6AEIJzAA |edition=12th |location=New York |publisher=Bowker |page=213 |isbn=0835208524 |access-date=3 August 2018 }}{{sfn|Cléroux|2013}} * {{cite book |year=1972 |editor1-last=Steegmuller |editor1-first=Francis |title=Flaubert in Egypt: A Sensibility on Tour. A Narrative Drawn from Gustave Flaubert's Travel Notes and Letters |location=Boston |publisher=Little, Brown }}{{sfn|Porter|2001|p=354}} * {{cite book |year=1979–1982 |editor1-last=Steegmuller |editor1-first=Francis |title=The Letters of Gustave Flaubert |location=Cambridge, Mass. |publisher=Belknap Press of Harvard University Press }} In two volumes. Jean Bruneau, editor of the then half-completed Pléiade edition, gave Steegmuller unfettered access to all his files, including the manuscripts of newly-discovered letters, with the result that some appeared in Steegmuller's English before they had been published in the original French. Its publication, ''[[The Times]]'' later said, "was a major event in the English-speaking literary world".{{cite news |author= |title=Francis Steegmuller |work=The Times |location=London |date=27 October 1994 |page=21 }}{{sfn|Barnes|2003}}{{cite book |last1=Patton |first1=Susannah |year=2010 |title=A Journey into Flaubert's Normandy |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=f36b0lAi0aMC&pg=PA248&dq=%22Press+1979+The+Letters+of+Gustave%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjlzvzsgtTcAhUFAsAKHYHeADoQ6AEILTAB#v=onepage&q=%22Press%201979%20The%20Letters%20of%20Gustave%22&f=false |location=Surry Hills, NSW |publisher=Accessible Publishing Systems |page=248 |isbn=9781458785435 |access-date=4 August 2018 }} * {{cite book |year=1985 |editor1-last=Beaumont |editor1-first=Barbara |title=Flaubert and Turgenev, a Friendship in Letters. The Complete Correspondence |location=London |publisher=Athlone }}{{sfn|Le Calvez|2001|p=76}} * {{cite book |translator-last1=Steegmuller |translator-first1=Francis |translator-last2=Bray |translator-first2=Barbara |translator-link2=Barbara Bray |year=1993 |title=Flaubert-Sand: The Correspondence |location=New York |publisher=Alfred A. Knopf }} Includes about 100 letters not to be found in the 1922 Mckenzie translation. Barbara Bray translated George Sand's letters, and Francis Steegmuller Flaubert's. It has been called "a graceful and expressive translation in a scrupulous edition that has the effect of the best kind of biography – and a double one at that."{{cite news |last=Fields |first=Beverly |date=7 March 1993 |title=Flaubert and Sand: Linked by Excellence |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1993-03-07/entertainment/9303188035_1_flaubert-and-sand-flaubert-sand-suffrage |work=Chicago Tribune |access-date=4 August 2018 }}{{cite news |last=Shattuck |first=Roger |author-link=Roger Shattuck |date=21 February 1993 |title=Pen Pals par Excellence |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/02/21/books/pen-pals-par-excellence.html |work=New York Times |access-date=4 August 2018 }} * {{cite book |translator-last1=Wall |translator-first1=Geoffrey |year=1997 |title=Selected Letters |location=Baltimore |publisher=Penguin }}{{sfn|Porter|2001|p=355}} == Footnotes == {{Reflist|2}} == References == * {{cite book |last1=Barnes |first1=Julian |year=2002 |orig-year=2001 |title=Something to Declare |location=Leicester |publisher=W F Howes |isbn=1841975435 }} * {{cite news |last=Barnes |first=Julian |date=28 June 2003 |title=Worlds Within Words |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2003/jun/28/classics.julianbarnes |work=The Guardian |location=London |access-date=2 August 2018 }} * {{cite web |url=http://flaubert.univ-rouen.fr/article.php?id=12 |title=Correspondance de Gustave Flaubert: Bibliographie des éditions et des études (1884–2013) |last=Cléroux |first=Gilles |date=2013 |website=Gustave Flaubert |publisher=Centre Flaubert, Université de Rouen |language=French |access-date=2 August 2018 }} * {{cite book |last1=Le Calvez |first1=Eric J |year=2001 |chapter=Correspondance |editor1-last=Porter |editor1-first=Laurence M |title=A Gustave Flaubert Encyclopedia |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=0La_MdsveVoC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |location=Westport, Conn. |publisher=Greenwood Press |isbn=031330744X |access-date=2 August 2018 }} * {{cite web |url=http://flaubert.univ-rouen.fr/correspondance/edition/ |title=Correspondence de Flaubert |editor1-last=Leclerc |editor1-first=Yvan |editor2-last=Girard |editor2-first=Danielle |date=2 November 2017 |website=Correspondence: Édition électronique |publisher=Centre Flaubert, Université de Rouen |language=French |access-date=2 August 2018 }} * {{cite book |last1=Lloyd |first1=Rosemary |year=2004 |chapter=Flaubert's Correspondence |editor1-last=Unwin |editor1-first=Timothy |title=The Cambridge Companion to Flaubert |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=swghAwAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |location=Cambridge |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=0521815517 |access-date=2 August 2018 }} * |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=0La_MdsveVoC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |location=Westport, Conn. |publisher=Greenwood Press |isbn=031330744X |access-date=4 August 2018 }} * {{cite book |year=1954 |editor1-last=Steegmuller |editor1-first=Francis |title=The Selected Letters of Gustave Flaubert |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=S8PStwEACAAJ |location=London |access-date=2 August 2018 }} == External links == * [https://archive.org/stream/cu31924027323587#page/n6 The McKenzie translation of the Flaubert–Sand letters] * {{Refimprove|date=January 2015}} The '''Gruber Collection''' is a collection of books and manuscripts housed at the [[Lutheran School of Theology at Chicago]] in [[Chicago]], Illinois. The collection contain more than 300 books from the 15th to 18th centuries and 14 manuscripts of Greek New Testament (minuscules and lectionaries). Special value have works of [[Martin Luther|Luther]], copies of his letters, original letters written by [[Philipp Melanchthon]], the [[Novum Instrumentum omne|Greek New Testament]] of Erasmus,<ref>[http://collections.lstc.edu/gruber/ref_docs/erasmus.php] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090101090802/http://collections.lstc.edu/gruber/ref_docs/erasmus.php |date=January 1, 2009 }}</ref> and other documents of [[Protestant Reformation|Reformation]] era.<ref name=Gruber>[http://collections.lstc.edu/gruber/about.php] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081229224117/http://collections.lstc.edu/gruber/about.php |date=December 29, 2008 }}</ref> All manuscripts and majority of books were collected by [[L. Franklin Gruber]] (1870–1941), the former president of the [[Lutheran School of Theology at Chicago]] in [[Maywood, Illinois]].<ref name = Gruber/> He purchased them in Europe and brought to Chicago.<ref>[[Bruce M. Metzger]], [[Bart D. Ehrman]], "The Text of the New Testament: Its Transmission, Corruption and Restoration", ''[[Oxford University Press]]'' (New York - Oxford, 2005), p. 90-91.</ref>
== Manuscripts == * Gruber 44 (Gregory [[Minuscule 1282|1282]]) * Gruber 50 (Gregory 2304) * Gruber 52 (Gregory '''ℓ''' ''1536'') * Gruber 53 (Gregory '''ℓ''' ''1624'') * Gruber 56 (Gregory '''ℓ''' ''1625'') * [[Lectionary 304|Gruber 111]] (Gregory '''ℓ''' ''1677'') * Gruber 114 (Gregory 2426) * Gruber 119 (Gregory 2389) * Gruber 122 (Gregory 2393) * Gruber 124 (Gregory '''ℓ''' ''1627'') * Gruber 125 (Gregory '''ℓ''' ''1628'') * until 2016: Gruber 152 (Gregory [[Minuscule 1424|1424]])<ref>In 2016, the LSTC decided to restitute the manuscript to the Kosinitza monastery.[http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-hyde-park-ancient-manuscript-met-20161114-story.html ''Hyde Park seminary to return 9th century New Testament to Greek Orthodox Church''], [[Chicago Tribune]], November 15, 2016</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * Kenneth W. Clark, "A Descriptive Catalogue of Greek New Testament Manuscripts in North America". Chicago: ''[[The University of Chicago Press]]'', 1937, pp. 90–106.
==External links== * [http://gruber.lstc.edu The Gruber Rare Books Collection] at the LSTC * [http://gruber.lstc.edu/nt_manuscripts/index.php New Testament manuscripts] at the LSTC * [http://prophetess.lstc.edu/~books/Documents/gruber.htm L. Franklin Gruber]
